p: The limited range of conventional and effective antifungal agents against Trichophyton spp. and the possible appearance of unpleasant adverse effects on the host are linked to safety problems and have lead to the search for a new, effective broad-spectrum combination of drug and natural antifungal. It is known that T. rubrum exhibited a relatively higher production of virulence factors, such as keratinase and elastase, which can degrade the skin structural barrier and immune cells [ 23, 31]. The synergy between drugs and essential oils could allow the use of lower doses of azoles in an effective and safe way, offering a promising use of this combination with TTO in the future pharmaceutical preparation for cutaneous mycoses management. In fact, some studies [ 23, 32] showed that certain essentials oils and their components ( Thymus vulgaris, thymol, C.copticum, and Origanum vulgare) are able to inhibit elastase in T. rubrum [ 32].
